review_comments.body: We are employing the icon set found at www/bootstrap/glyphicons and deprecating the old images/icons/icon_\* icons. It would be better to choose one of those glyphicons. They are typically used like so:
Are these XSS safe?

I have been removing the word "Note" when using print_info_box. info boxes are notes by definition so it is not needed. I have also removed unneeded phrases such as "Click here to . ." and "Options entered here . . "
images/\* have been deprecated. Please use a glyphicons if possible

Thanks Phil,

Rant very much understood. I have learned that “converted” in the context of this project often meant “Looks pretty but completely untested”. You know the issues as well as (perhaps better) than me. My goal is to have the functionality restored to all pages by the end of this week, and then to start a month-long code review/QC process. I can’t tell you how much I value your help in this. It’s priceless.

commit_comments.body:
Yes, but in this case I don't know the interface. I'm killing states on LAN interfaces when WAN ppp-linkdown is called, for example:

pppoe0 tcp Lan_subnet_ip:port -> pppoe_IP:port -> target_ip:port
lan_if tcp lan_subnet_ip:port <- target_ip:port

Without the change, all NAT states from pppoe0 are killed, but firewall states on lan_if don't.
Fixed, thanks!
Already fixed on master but not pushed yet since I'm doing other changes there.
Thanks for pointing that.

```

```

What I meant is, without this change, you already are able to add both forms, there is no check preventing you to do it. And with the change, if you add a single email address (e.g. renato@pfsense.org) it's going to be modified to "renato renato@pfsense.org" because preg_match at line 353 is going to match every char before '@'.

I don't think it's a good idea, it would just add more complication with no gain. You can improve the text that describe the field in that form so users will be aware they can use both formats. I'm going to close this PR. Thanks!

Check for /bootpool and import the bootpool zfs pool if present. Fixes #8063

We set prompt=no, so most of these values will cause an error when openssl commands are run directly.
When crafting the CA subject for ipsec.conf, handle component values that are arrays. Fixes #7929
When ntp is bound to specific interfaces, disable listening on wildcard. Fixes #8046
Add an option for LDAP servers to use the global root CA list as a peer CA. Fixes #8044
Fix handling of wildcard CN/SAN entries in certificates. Fixes #7994
Ensure that a certificate authority entry is capable of acting as a CA when importing. Fixes #7885
Reindex the user and group arrays after deleting items, to avoid operating on incorrect array entries. Fixes #7733
Change a few more instances of using the physical interface to the friendly interface in status_queues.php, which allows root queues to function with the new VLAN interface names. Fixes #8007
Do not print JS when there are input errors on diag_dns.php; fix json_encode syntax. Ticket #7999
Do not allow direct download of .inc files (unparsed PHP source). Fixes #8005
Fix status_queues.php for the new VLAN interface format. Fixes #8007
Encode uses of $widgetkey in various contexts so it isn't echoed back to the user raw. Fixes #7998
Widget instance counter must be numeric. Fixes #8000
Encode hostname parameter contents in javascript for diag_dns.php. Fixes #7999
Do not reconfigure wireless on a link up event, or else it can get stuck in a loop. Fixes #7960
Allow both AES-NI and Crypto modules to be loaded at the same time. Fixes #7810

issue_comments.body:
Not sure why you need to modify upgrade_config.inc at all, that won't be touched for normal operations, only when upgrading from 1.2.3 to 2.0 and since LDAP+IPsec was not supported there, there is no need to make any consideration for that.

The racoon bits look ok, but you should have a test surrounding that code block that only writes them out if the user source is LDAP. As it is, it would put the LDAP config in every racoon config, even those not using LDAP. Also a sanity test to make sure that the referenced LDAP server exists would be useful.

Would also be nice if the LDAP choice was hidden if no LDAP servers were defined, and if you have more than one LDAP server defined, there should be a way to choose between them. (the latter could wait, since this is going into 2.1, so long as a ticket was opened in redmine to remind someone to finish it off before 2.1 ships.)

What is the real purpose of this?

The function you have would only return true if that CA exists on pfSense, which can be done already with lookup_ca() and a check for a valid return.

It would be a bit unusual to have a certificate listed in both the CA manager and Certs tab, and even if it was in both, the refid would be different so this would never match.

The CAs and Certs are in different arrays and lists, so it wouldn't work as written. The certs under $config['cert'] are just certificates, not necessarily a CA, those should be under $config['ca'].

And cert_cert_purpose() can already return if a cert is actually a CA even if it's just in the Cert list, and on 2.1 it already displays the actual uses under the Name column.
Could you redo this without all of the random whitespace changes and with a more accurate commit message?
It's in the master branch (2.1) which is where any new features should be going.

Yeah even if that code went into RELENG_2_0 you wouldn't see it in a release for several months, assuming we do another 2.0.x release at all. If your package needs that code, you may just want to put that code to check it inside the package's .inc file.

Sign up for the dev list and ask there.

commits.message:
"Save" user selection for DUID type

It proved confusing for users who entered a DUID as a certain type to
see the resulting DUID file displayed as a "Raw DUID" upon page reload.
Still work with dhcp6c_duid file data, but parse it and show the Form
corresponding to the DUID type with the inputs filled in, so the user
sees what she previously entered.

Raw edits to the DUID file are still possible.

Remove endianness checking

all pfSense builds are little-endian

Code cleanup
Add a check to Copy DUID button on system_advanced_network.php

Support for configuring additional DUID types

dhcp6c stores the entirety of the OPTION_CLIENTID option in DHCPv6 datagrams in
its DUID file (named dhcp6c_duid), except for the option code itself. The first
two octets in the DUID file are the option-len field, and are saved according to
machine order. The remainder is the option-data field in network order.

Support configuring current and future DUID types in webConfigurator.
Save and read option-len correctly in the DUID file for the machine type (was
probably broken before on ARM).

DHCPv6 option fmt: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3315#section-22.1
OPTION_CLIENTID:   https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3315#section-22.2
DUID types:        https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3315#section-9.1,
                   https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6355

Add isset, other vars seem to use it

Doesn't seem to have a point though :)
typo

Unbound: Disable IPv6 outgoing queries if IPv6 blocked in firewall, as they can never go anywhere

If IPv6 is disallowed in system->advanced->network, then any IPv6 lookups by Unbound will always be blocked, so there's no point sending them.

The practical purpose is that they also clog up the log and may fractionally slow down the resolver because the resolver then has to deal with IPv6 not replying, fallback lookups, etc.

I'm aware that we state that the system setting doesn't affect any service, but in this case the service simply doesn't send packets that we know will be blocked anyway on egress, so it's probably not going to be an issue. If it is, we can add an explicit "Disable IPv6" setting to this and other functions, but then if IPv6 is later used, the user has to remember to unset "IPv6 not allowed" in all the pages they were set, which is a pain and pretty much duplicates the main setting for all practical purposes.

correct %d -> %s

As previous code used a string. Probably makes no difference and a number is simpler but doesn't matter

Clarify the unexplained numbers in "log verbosity"

At the moment verbosity is a bare list of digits, 0 to 5. No explanation, nothing else. This PR replaces the visible text by user-friendly info as to what will be logged. Source is https://www.unbound.net/documentation/unbound.conf.html

pull_requests.title: Rework on "system_usermanager_settings" and "system_authservers"
pull_requests.body:
I refactored these two pages, although the underlying code isn't changed at all.

The session timeout in user manager settings hasn't got much to do with individual users or their permissions / authentication, it's a global timeout setting far closer to other admin security measures controlling security of logins on WebGUI sessions which are without exception all under **system -> advanced admin"**. Long standing "urgh". The two pages have 3 other functions split between them which are very closely related - (1) view a list of auth servers, (2) select an auth server, and (3) edit auth servers. It seems very unhelpful to have (1) + (3) on the same page (via add/edit buttons) and (2) as a solo control on a different page, so I've put the GUI auth selection dropdown on the same page as the list of auth servers, which works nicely and makes logical sense.  That left nothing on usermanager_settings, which seems reasonable - it only had 2 controls, one related to admin access security and the other to selecting an auth server, neither was related to the user manager itself. Finally for code simplicity, I split **system_authservers.php** into two files, one for the table display and the other for entry editing, creating a new `system_authservers_edit.php` page from the existing code, because that function really is quite long and complex - basically it's exactly how it's done on other pages with a substantial edit page (such as firewall_rules.php + firewall_rules_edit.php).

**tl;dr summary:**

- `usermanager_settings.php` removed. There _weren't_ any settings for the user manager itself, it only had 2 controls, and both were very closely tied to other pages (one much more related to admin security but unhelpfully, not kept with other admin security functions, and the other related to how users authenticate rather than any settings of the usermanager). The controls moved with their code intact, one moved to `system->advanced admin`, the other to `system->user manager -> authentication servers`. They look a lot more at home there, and much easier for GUI users.  

- `system_authservers.php` was very substantial because of all the auth settings for editing an auth server. In that regard it's closer to firewall rules, which have a separate settings page. It basically forked at `head.inc` to output both the main and edit pages. I split it into 2 pages the same way as firewall rules pages and others - a main page (containing the table and "add" button", and an edit page.  This also let me be fairly sure that it wouldn't would cause issues, and kept the PR much simpler, by making it a direct copypaste with only minor changes.

- I then added the `GUI login auth server selector` code to be above the table on authservers.

- I deliberately avoided code change to the underlying code for ease of review.  It's basically copy-paste + minor glue. The only changes are as follows:  (1) Minor UI wording improvements on authserver.gui form, to be clearer what the selector is for, see screenshot, (2) Minor enhancements to validity checking on $_POST/$_REQUEST, (3) simplifying the args for the new `authservers_edit.php`:  it doesn't need `?act=new/edit` in its links now, and can be simplified like firewall_rules_edit.php: the presence of a valid `?id=` signifies edit, anything else signifies new. So I simplified that aspect and $act is set based on `id`.  (4) consequential edits to`help.php` + `priv.defs.inc` (because of the new page and removed page), and other user manager subpages (to remove the usermanager_settings tab),

I don't use LDAP or other auth servers myself which limits checking, but I haven't modified the code knowingly other than peripheral as described, and the redone code looks good here from what I can see. Much more intuitive and simpler.

Screenshot below.

pull_requests.title: Convert ICMP subtypes selector control in fw_rules_edit.php as suggested, and refactor jscript a little
pull_requests.body:
See PR #3328 for background.

This PR converts the new ICMP subtypes selector in `firewall_rules_edit.php` from a single multi-select list box to a double selector, as suggested by @jim-p, which leaves it clearer and more obvious which items are selected, without adding a list of checkboxes.

It does indeed improve the form. 

I hope no "junk" or merge conflicts have made it into this, I have worked from a copy-paste of the current code, but mistakes are always possible.

I also refactored the javascript by collecting all functions and all on load activities together ("like with like") for convenience of devs in future. However all code except that directly controlling ICMP subtype selection should be unchanged.

The only functional change to the form is that it now returns icmptype as a comma separated string via a hidden control, rather than as an array of elements from the list box (as in the example suggested by @jim-p in the original PR). This made the code simpler, because the source data for the "selected" list box was already generated from a JS array anyhow, and the data in $config is in that format.

pull_requests.title: Add comprehensive high-level ip_compare() function

commit_comments.body: I've added some info to the original thread on the "to !/" artifact bug which may be useful.

review_comments.body:
Can you say a bit more, Im not sure I know which you are referring to.

Anticipating what you might mean: - inet_ntop() returned FALSE if the IP isn't valid, which meant it rolled validation and conversion into one function, which was efficient. When I avoided inet_ntop(), I had to look again at validation. I noticed that ip2long() does validate its argument, but this wasn't available in ip_compare() because it wasn't detected or trapped in ip2long32() or ip2ulong(). Which meant those 2 functions could have validation errors in some cases too.  So the updated PR has these two functions aware of the possibility that ip2long() may return FALSE or zero, and ensures these aren't confused.

In other words, ip_compare() only uses ip2ulong (like the original code), but ip2ulong() uses ip2long32() internally so both are fixed.  

If that's not an answer to your question can you clarify which lines contain the same test done 2 different ways?, so I can answer what you asked :)

pull_requests.title: Widget refresh fix; minor widget UI tweaks
pull_requests.body:
executewidget
- Renamed function to executewidgets for grammar's sake
- Moved ajaxspecs.length check out of the loop - if ajaxspecs.length isn't more than 0 at page load, there's no reason to keep checking it. can always move the check back into executewidgets function if there ever arises a case where widgets can be inserted into ajaxspecs dynamically.
- Changed to a setInterval instead of a self-calling setTimeout - code is cleaner that way
- Fixed logic in widget loop - previously, the setTimeout loop was only incrementing ajaxidx every time it was executed, which means that the function is only checking one single widget every second. If you have 6 widgets registered (my case, for example), that means that the loop only comes back around to a given widget (log.widget.php for example) every 6th run. So if you have your interval set to 1, it actually only refreshes every 6 seconds; if the interval is set to 2, it refreshes every 12 seconds. Changed ajaxidx to a for loop, checking each widget every setInterval execution.

make_ajax_call
- Improved logic flow - should be doing your failure checks, then continuing if no failures are detected
- Cleaned up unnecessary variable ajaxtimeout - don't need to capture this in a variable if it's not checked elsewhere
- Cleaned up unnecessary variable ajaxmutex - you shouldn't use a global widget lock; see next point for replacement
- Added a per-widget lock, which expires regardless of success or failure

pull_requests.title: Improve flexibility of DHCPD configuration
pull_requests.body:
- New checkbox "Virtual IPs" to allow dhcpd to use ipalias subnets
- Allow creation of static mappings on ipalias subnets

I've minimally tested this. It's mostly for comment at this point. 

This is a very minimal effort to allow creation of dhcpd static host configurations on ipalias subnets. It is enabled by checking the "Virtual IPs" checkbox on the DHCPD service configuration view. Once enabled, the user will be able to create static mappings with addresses that match any subnet bound to the interface, including ipalias address subnets.

In order to facilitate this change, once enabled, the dhcpd.conf is modified to include all subnets of a given interface within a "shared-network" block named for the interface the subnets live on. No options are allowed within ipalias subnets.

This is as far as I'd like to go with this feature, but it could be expanded to allow for "Additional Pools" to be created within the ipalias subnets. I did some work towards this, but have stopped as it becomes very difficult to validate the new pools and all of their options without a major refactor if services_dhcp.php.

Know issues:
- Once "Virtual IPs" is disabled, the out of subnet static mappings remain
- dhcpd.conf indentation is inconsistent

pull_requests.title: Update nsswitch when 'Disable DNS Forwarder'
pull_requests.body:
tl;dr firewall services use /etc/hosts when it shouldn't

[Edit: fixed the paragraph width and added replication example]

Services on the firewall continue to use unbound for lookups when /etc/resolv.conf is configured for the forward resolvers.

This affected my OpenVPN client running on the firewall where my LAN has public hosts being overridden to the VPN IP addresses (including the VPN server). The OpenVPN client does a DNS lookup via /etc/hosts because of the /etc/nsswitch.conf config and tries to connect to the internal IP I configured in unbound for the LAN hosts, rather than public IP returned by the configured resolvers. This caused the VPN to fail to connect because it was trying to connect to the wrong IP. This also affected ntpd and likely every service as nsswitch was working as configured.

Replication steps:

Variables:

Public VPN Server IP: `123.45.67.89`
Public VPN Server hostname: `vpn.domain.tld`
Internal VPN Server IP: `10.3.2.1/24`
Internal VPN Serer hostname: `vpn.domain.tld`

pfSense configurations:

Services / DNS Resolver / General Settings / Host Overrides
`vpn.domain.tld`: `10.3.2.1`

On disk configuration:

`/etc/resolv.conf`:
```
search domain.tld
nameserver 8.8.8.8
nameserver 8.8.4.4
```

`/etc/hosts`
```
10.3.2.1 vpn.domain.tld
```

`/etc/nsswitch.conf`
```
...
hosts: files dns
...
```

When OpenVPN attempts to connect to `"vpn.domain.tld"` it resolves this host to `"10.3.2.1"` and fails to connect because there it no route to host.

This is happening because `/etc/nsswitch` resolves `"vpn.domain.tld"` to the definition in `/etc/hosts` rather than doing a lookup against `8.8.8.8` (or `8.8.4.4`) as configured by the checkbox option.

The change swaps the `/etc/nsswitch.conf` host lookup order to use `/etc/resolv.conf` before checking `/etc/hosts` to resolve the hostname which is what I assumed the UI option would have done.

pull_requests.title: UI Tests for PfSense
pull_requests.body:
This implements UI tests for pfSense
The tests are based on phpunit and selenium and run on https://travis-ci.org and https://saucelabs.com

1. travis-ci downloads and boots an image of pfsense in qemu
2. pfsense is updated by `pfSense-upgrade -d -y` & `pfSsh.php playback gitsync master`
3. tests are run against the upgraded pfsense using selenium on saucelabs

How to run this tests locally:

1. download Selenium standalone server jar from http://docs.seleniumhq.org/download/
2. download the chromedriver from: https://sites.google.com/a/chromium.org/chromedriver/ and place it in the same folder as the selenium server
3. start selenium:`java -jar selenium-server-standalone-3.0.1.jar`
4. set the 3 environment variables: SRV_HOST_NAME, SRV_HOST_URL and SRV_HOST_PORT to wherever your dev. environment runs e.g.:
```
export SRV_HOST_NAME=localhost
export SRV_HOST_URL=pfsense
export SRV_HOST_PORT=80
```
5. install php composer:
```
php -r "copy('https://getcomposer.org/installer', 'composer-setup.php');"
php -r "if (hash_file('SHA384', 'composer-setup.php') === '55d6ead61b29c7bdee5cccfb50076874187bd9f21f65d8991d46ec5cc90518f447387fb9f76ebae1fbbacf329e583e30') { echo 'Installer verified'; } else { echo 'Installer corrupt'; unlink('composer-setup.php'); } echo PHP_EOL;"
php composer-setup.php
php -r "unlink('composer-setup.php');"
```
6. install composer dependencies: `php composer.phar install`
7. run tests: `vendor/bin/phpunit -c tests/phpunit-selenium-autotest.xml`

test view on travis: https://travis-ci.org/individual-it/pfsense/builds/202541766
test view on saucelabs: https://saucelabs.com/beta/tests/b3085d9422cb49bdac8f19d0d3550581

pull_requests.title: Captive portal: add support for setting traffic quotas
pull_requests.body:
This patch series add support for traffic quotas to the captive portal.

Patch 1 ("always use the RADIUS-provided session timeout value if the option is enabled") isn't directly related but fixes an issue where the RADIUS attribute could be ignored if there was a shorter hard timeout configured; now when the option is set the RADIUS attribute is always honored.

Patch 2 ("add a traffic quota option") adds an option to set the maximum amount of traffic (sum of downloads and uploads) that a user is allowed to generate during a session. As it happens with the hard timeout setting, the client will still be able to reconnect immediately.

Patch 3 ("add option to retrieve the traffic quota value from RADIUS") allows to get the value of the traffic quota from a RADIUS server. The value obtained is recorded in a new column in the active sessions' database, requiring some minor changes to use the right index to retrieve the radius context in other parts of the code. Since the feature uses a new vendor-specific attribute and I couldn't find a pfSense dictionary, I created a new one (see also the next patch), using Netgate's SMI Network Management Private Enterprise Code as per RFC. I defined 5 attributes, respectively to set upload quota, download quota, total quota, max upload bandwidth and max download bandwidth, even though only the total quota one is used in this patch series (I think the existing code should do the right thing for the bandwidth limits but I didn't test it). I hope this is OK.

Patch 4 ("Add RADIUS dictionary with definitions of the new pfSense vendor-specific attributes") is the new FreeRADIUS compatible dictionary file for pfsense I was talking about earlier. The directory in which I placed it likely isn't the right place, in theory the dictionary, once approved, should be submitted to FreeRADIUS for inclusion and in the meantime added to the FreeRADIUS pkg available in pfSense. Till then tho it will have to be distributed in some other way to allow users who want to use the feature to manually add it to their FreeRADIUS server configuration.

I'm not sure this or its feature request is a good idea. SSH doesn't log that much, and the system log is generally pretty clean since the verbose things are split into their own logs. There's a limit to how many logging tabs it's sane to have, and we need to keep segregation to things that are verbose. If SSH justifies its own, 200 other things could justify their own, and we end up with a gigantic logging mess. Am I missing something that makes this clearly useful and justifiable?

The problem is if we had a log tab for everything that someone out there thought was a good idea, we'd have 500 of them. The only time SSH generates much log volume is when people have SSH wide open to the Internet and are getting brute forced. That's stupidity to keep open, accommodating people who ignore sane practices isn't something we do. Even that gets them locked out after 15 attempts so the flood is limited at least until the next bot comes along. Under normal, sane circumstances, the volume of logs never justifies segregating them. 

I'm leaning towards closing that feature request and the merge request, but will reconsider later.
SSH isn't verbose enough in any configuration that should be deployed in the real world to justify a logging tab.

commit_comments.body: I don't think that's an issue anymore, IIRC Ermal changed some other things over to not do that and it hasn't been an issue. We really can't dump the entire routing table, hosts with full BGP feeds will hang up for several minutes while doing so. Granted, they generally aren't running reflection, so it doesn't matter as much here, but still something that needs to be stayed away from. Ermal's done a lot of work taking out full route table dumps to make things work reasonably on hosts with full BGP routing tables, need to keep that working.

This suggested syntax is actually already in use for messages in various places for the purpose of allowing translators to change the order of the inserted strings where needed.  The number specifies which parameter is inserted at the location.

If they know about it, I suppose technically a translator could use the %1$s, %2$s, etc. syntax in the translation even if it isn't in the original, but having it in the original would make it a bit more clear what can be done in the translation.

Is that on the 32-bit version?  If so, only the amount that is really available to the OS should matter there.  The sizes of pf data structures should not be based on memory that the OS has not made available for use.

If there is an issue when having more than 2 GB of RAM, I would suggest that it is PHP's fault.  If there is some way of handling larger numbers on the 32-bit version of PHP, it could probably resolve this.

Using a signed int on the 32-bit version would make anything above 2 GB look like a negative amount of memory, which would indeed be less than 100 MB in the comparison it does there.  Would this section of code be making pf ignore whatever increased size the pfSense scripts are telling it to use?

I tried putting the array of defaults in the top of gwlb.inc - then function setup_gateways_monitor() directly below did not see the array. Somehow in the way it al gets included, an array in the top of gwlb.inc does not end up in scope for a function in gwlb.inc - I don't understand that.
I added the defaults as an array in globals.inc and used it in gwlb.inc and system_gateway_edit.php without a problem.
For the validation tests, I enhanced/touch nearly all of them anyway, so while dong that I replaced some spaces with tabs in my editor. Not sure how easily I can put back all the spaces the way they were.

I will make another pull request and you can comment - I don't really like adding to globals.inc - that is something that needs to be carefully thought about by you developers and not just allowed to grow biger and bigger. These defaults are only wanted in a couple of places, not necessarily across every bit of the system.

Let me know if there is a preferred way to implement this, rather than putting the apinger_default array into globals.inc
I tried just putting it at the top of gwlb.inc, but for some reason even function setup_gateways_monitor() just below in gwlb.inc could not see the array values. Something in the way things get included?
Anyway, it works fine with the defaults in globals.inc - the defaults are available to all the places that need them.

The variables become global and are accessible inside function setup_gateways_monitor and from the body of system_gateways_edit.php once I add:
global $phil_arr;
global $phil_var;
to gwlb.inc just before I set them.
The tricky part of this varibale and function scope in PHP is:
"All functions and classes in PHP have the global scope - they can be called outside a function even if they were defined inside and vice versa. " - http://php.net/manual/en/language.functions.php
So, when a ".inc" file gets require_once the first time, then functions declared inside it always become globally available. But ordinary variables in it only become available to the scope in which the require_once was done, which is not always at the top/first "global" level/file. So to make sure that things go in the global namespace, they should always be declared global.
Enough dribble about that - at least it is here for others to read and to remind myself.

I can see 3 ways to go:
a) add to globals.inc, which seems to get included at the top-level and so the variables in it are in the global scope. (the current pull request)
b) put the variables into the top of gwlb.inc and declare them global, then just make sure that anything that uses the variables has included gwlb.inc somewhere along the way. This saves exposing apinger_defaults to everything when only 2 or 3 things use it.
c) Add a function get_apinger_defaults to gwlb.inc, make it return an array of default values. Then anything that cares can call get_apinger_defaults and use the values. This saves polluting the global namespace with this rubbish. This mechanism can be used for any bunch of default values that is needed by only a few modules.

Looking at it now, I think (c) is the best policy for "constant" defaults that are only used by a few modules.
Let me know what is preferred - it should be a development team policy/standard that can be done the same way by others, rather than implementing "random" different ways of passing "constant" defaults around the code.

Yep, I agree.
For completeness, I also forgot to mention option (d):
d) Use define() to define constants. Constants are always global, so visible everywhere as soon as they are defined. Drawbacks - cannot have constant arrays, so the namespace gets polluted with a separate constant name for every value needed (apinger_latencylow_default, apinger_latencyhigh_default...). Can't be substituted easily inside quotes and heredocs... - I don't think we want to define() constants.

I will close this pull request and make another one implementing option (c).

On the "10" thing (previous commits). I come from projects where we always tried to use a name for any constant "magic number" in the code, specially when it appears multiple times. That makes future maintenance easier - if someone needs to change "10" to "42" for some reason, then it can be done in 1 place, there is no need to hunt through the code for "10" and then work out which "10"s should be changed to "42" and which were a use of "10" for another purpose.

Note: The first 2 tests are needed - to NOT need a resync, the current device must already be the selected "best" device from the gateway group (new device), AND it must not be the device that has just gone down/up. (e.g. if the current device is the new (best) device, but that device has just come up, then we need to resync OpenVPN anyway. It needs to start listening (server) or making outbound connect attempts (client) from scratch again. And old version of the OpenVPN instance may or may not be running and may or may not recover in this instance.
The 3rd comparison is redundant, when current_device == new_device then the 2nd and 3rd tests are effectively the same. I had put it in originally, and left it there for "clarity" - if the new device is the device that just came up then we certainly want to resync OpenVPN. Maybe the "clarity" is confusion for readers who notice that the 3rd test is redundant.

This one is trying to calculate the total (t) bytes on the interface. The calculation was just weird - the number of bytes passed in plus the number of bytes blocked out. IMHO it has to be simple - total bytes passed plus total bytes blocked.

issue_comments.body:
Hi Ermal,

Thanks for the reply.

There is PPTP client functionality of sorts in pfSense already, but it's  
functionality is very limited and doesn't allow the configuration of the  
most critical aspects of authentication, compression or encryption nor  
does it allow the addition of arbitrary routes to the remote network. One  
could use the "Routing" pages to manually add the required routes each  
time the tunnel is brought up. But this is a frankly a pain and an  
unnecessary administration burden. All this together, means that  
connection attempts to anything but an unencrypted PPTP server generally  
fail and even if it does connect successfully, traffic often doesn't get  
properly routed to the remote network.

I believe that the original implementation of the PPTP client was only  
intended for use with ISP that require this protocol for authentication  
over A/DSL connections. In Australia, no ISP uses this technique, but many  
people here run their own private PPTP servers (usually on Windows) and  
require configuration, specifically of the MPPE/MPPC options. I certainly  
have a use for this in my job as Systems Engineer for a home automation  
company in Melbourne Australia, where we will make judicious use of  
persistent tunnels between pfSense boxes all over the world. We are  
intending to use this for several of our clients who require multiple  
client connections from their homes to their workplaces. As pfSense  
doesn't currently support mutli-passthrough of PPTP client connections, we  
felt that a persistent tunnel (or several) from the pfSesne FW itself  
would be an option as the tunnel/s could then be managed with firewall  
rules, VLANS and possibly captive portals, to control local access to the  
remote network.

I'll update it to work with recent sources and re-submit the pull request.  
Thanks for your input.

Regards,

Ben.

Ermal,

This class file for Route 53 has been published at http://www.orderingdisorder.com/aws/route-53/ , i dont think that it are going to change soon.

It has basically 6 functions:

Create a new domain in Route 53: createHostedZone()
List Domain Info: getHostedZone()
Prepare xml to post into Route 53 API: prepareChange()
Send XML request to API: changeResourceRecordSets()
Get status of change that you submited: getChange()
List all records in your domain hosted in Route 53: listResourceRecordSets()

From this 6 i need last 4 to make my changes work. I dont think that we will save much space if we extract only this funcions from this library.

The last updated comment is being stripped out of the IPv6 bogons file and not available for diagnostics tables display.

There is no reason to strip out the comments from the bogons files as pfctrl is comment aware.
Instead insure the IPv6 private address space never gets included in the bogons.

The pfctrl result is multi-line... for example addresses added on one line and addresses deleted on the next line.

Using echo alone the first line is prefixed with the description and any subsequent lines are bare result.
So filtering the system log with description yields only the first line.  Such as the addresses added and not any others such as addresses deleted.

Using awk each pfctrl result line is prefixed with the description and the system log can then be filtered by description to get all the lines.

According to PHP documentation empty() will consider not only “” to be empty, as desired, but also 0 (as an integer), 0.0 (as a float), and “0” (as a string).  So if there was a friendly interface “0” it would be considered empty.  Even though it really is not.

What we really want is to echo the tilde when friendly interface for both IPv4 and IPv6 are both blank.

There is no necessity for the htmlspecialchars() call other than consistency, but doesn’t hurt anything.  Easy enough to remove.

From my notes on the subject...

to match the first 4 octets of the MAC address:

```
    match if (substring (hardware, 0, 5) = 01:00:19:66:f7 );
```

or, if you're Ethernet-only network, skip the initial "01":

```
    match if (substring (hardware, 1, 4) = 00:19:66:f7 );
```

Yes, IP phones and PCs was what the feature request (and the related discussion at the forum) was about.

Since I had to look up the syntax myself back then, I added the two examples for completeness. Maybe you can add a short comment in the code, that the first octet of the MAC addr that is skipped is the media type, typically Ethernet, type "01".

The whole file, the console has become unusable (won't accept ^C etc), endlessly repeating the message above.

11 | 111 )

But won't a redirect of https traffic simply produce a "big scary warning" by the user's browser (due to SSL cert mismatch) ?

Which is why I just blocked all other (non-80) traffic using reset tcp, unreach port udp

The only way that intercepting https wouldn't bomb, would be have all our clients import "our" root CA cert in their certificate store, and the captive portal to also be able to create the appropriate certificate on the fly, effectively performing a MiTM attack. Some commercial software does that, which is also how they monitor https traffic.

In every other case (that I'm aware of) the client's browser would complain about hostname mismatch (i.e. "we asked for www.gmail,com and the server certificate we got is for pfsense.mydomain.tld") even if the SSL cert itself is signed by a recognized CA ...

Does the sysctl report the correct value on systems with more than 2GB of RAM? FreeBSD only has the 32bit HW_PHYSMEM and no 64bit HW_PHYSMEM64 that OpenBSD and NetBSD have. In fact that was the reason for the pull request 313 as pf is using HW_PHYSMEM to determine the amount of memory and thus fails to properly set the 'limit table-entries' for systems with more than 2GB of RAM.
Should probably also contain the -n option

Just for the sake of completeness I decided to add the output of the various commands using yesterday's image.

Using 1G of RAM
![memory_1G](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1117411/71733/883b049a-5ff5-11e2-837e-6cdd7e9b0e4a.png)

Using 5G of RAM
![memory_5G](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1117411/71737/9573c3ae-5ff5-11e2-8671-80b67df9c2ff.png)

Yes indeed this is the 32bit version, ~~on the 64bit version everything is fine~~. (Actually it's not fine on 64bit versions as well, with 5GB it just wraps around back to a value > 100MB.) 

As you can see in the images above the only real problem was the default value for the table-entries which should only be set to 100000 if pf detects less than 100MB of RAM but that is broken if the system has more than 2GB of RAM [1]. I thought the sysctl binary would also not be working properly as pf is internally using the same sysctl command (HW_PHYSMEM) however it seems that only the pf memory detection is broken.

So using the patches that have just been included should solve the 'out of table-entries' problem for users running a 32bit version with more than 2GB of RAM. Realizing that only the detection in pf is broken, fixing that would have been an option as well.

[1] http://svnweb.freebsd.org/base/stable/8/contrib/pf/pfctl/pfctl.c?view=markup (line 1551)
[2] http://svnweb.freebsd.org/base/stable/8/sys/sys/sysctl.h?view=markup (~line 516)

Edit: Just realized that the sysctl information is conflicting. In [2] both physmem and realmem are stated to be of type int but they are actually defined as unsigned long. Thus changing the type of mem in pfctl.c (line 1518) from int to unsigned long would probably fix the bug.

No it's only the default value that is used when the pfSense script does not overwrite it. So the patches that have been introduced today change the behavior of pfSense to always overwrite that default value and do our own memory detection (which this commit is about).
In fact that behavior has only become evident since the introduction of the fullbogon lists that do not fit into a table with only 100000 entries.

review_comments.body: You should not use variables in a gettext call as the variable is resolved first. Instead use sprintf() to format the string e.g. sprintf(gettext("%d entries in this table."), $count). Also I find it quite strange that the link is (was) on the 'all' keyword and not on 'Delete'.

The problem with this solution is that the order of the gettext string parts and the '$count' variable is fixed, which may not work with all languages, with sprintf the translator is free to change the word order. In fact, ideally the whole 'Delete all %d entries this table' should be contained in a single gettext. 

There is a good introduction in how to 'Creating localizable web applications' in the Mozilla developer network.
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web_Localizability/Creating_localizable_web_applications

Sure the original version is not ideal either and it was just meant as a suggestion how to improve it as it makes it easier and more flexible for a translator without having to look at the code. ``` echo '

' . sprintf(gettext('Delete all %2$d entries in this table.'), 'diag_tables.php?deleteall=true&type='.htmlspecialchars($tablename), $count); ``` Or one could even use ngettext to also handle the plural forms.

Even though the $tablesname variable will only have the values "bogons" or "bogonsv6" in this case, I still suggest using escapeshellarg for all user input shell arguments. Also instead of directly concatenating you might want to store the output in a meaningful variable this would make the code more readable.

When you have multiple printf/sprintf fields in text being passed to gettext, it is probably best to number the fields when a translation may need to change the order that they are displayed.  For example, "Configure %s address %s interface via %s?  [y|n]" could instead use 'Configure %1$s address %2$s interface via %3$s?  [y|n]'

Note that it is probably best to use single quoted strings instead of double quoted strings with that syntax when possible, because otherwise you need to escape the $

Just FYI: removing mod_cgi breaks the lightsquid package entirely. Is this change to be permanent?

It looks to me like fastcgi is only configured to handle PHP scripts, but I could be wrong. I think the previous behavior was like this:

The Lighttpd configuration: cgi.assign = ( ".cgi" => "" ) would cause anything ending in the "cgi" extension to be parsed via mod_cgi based on the interpreter on the hashbang line, which in the case of Lightsquid's index.cgi file was: "#!/usr/bin/perl"

Without that cgi.assign configuration directive, there's not concession for .cgi files, so instead of being parsed by an interpreter, they're simply served over http as normal files.
So, would it be possible for that section to be put back?
Thanks. Lightsquid works as it should now.

commit_comments.body:
This is overriding a preexisting function below on line 494. From (http://www.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?query=pf.conf&apropos=0&sektion=5&manpath=FreeBSD+8.3-RELEASE&arch=default&format=html#STATEFUL_TRACKING_OPTIONS) that we referred too, there is no traffic prerequisite for using any stateful tracking options except "max-src-conn" and "max-src-conn-rate" which are TCP only, as you have them currently. With the newer change to the filter.inc function we were working on (https://github.com/pfsense/pfsense/commit/dde3cae3dcbd7b64757c66acc4b56f1183831ede) that brings light to this fact, shouldn't some of these validation rules also be changed to reflect this? And while we're here, remove the double occurrence of "if (!empty($_POST['max'])". The function that states the rule must simply be a pass type rule being more correct.

I think the basis for rule validation, rather than protocol, should be state type, as described at the very top of the linked section above: "A number of options related to stateful tracking can be applied on a per-rule basis. keep state, modulate state and synproxy state support these options, and keep state must be specified explicitly to apply options to a rule." So any protocol of any state type (basically any pass rule) can use all state options, while keep state must be specified to use the two TCP only "max-src-conn" and "max-src-conn-rate" state options.

Am I making sense here?

Ahhh I see what you're saying now, the two different functions do make sense.

You're right about usability of .0/.255 but what about routing issues? Personally, I've never used/saw a .0/.255 in real networks. Before implementing I've done some research and found out that some customers with .0/.255 were not be reachable from WAN in some cases and other "issues". Issues were not because IP address was a network identifier/broadcast address but only .0/.255 itself. So, I've decided to implement "safe" method.

For example, my implementation allows to use .32 (network identifier) or .39 (broadcast addr) if you have a 192.168.0.32/29 network; 

That's perfectly correlates with your message and smaller subnets. If you meant something like 182.11.0.0/31 I wonder if ISP could give you one.

Also, pfSense box could not be a border gateway. What if border gateway (for example, ISA/TMG) will not be able to route or .0/.255 will be blocked by security policy?

Can you be more specific? 
Thank you.
